abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Third Primary
            Education Project for Pakistan was unsatisfactory. The
            project did not achieve its objectives, its impact on
            institutional development was negligible, sustainability is
            uncertain, and the performance of the Bank was satisfactory
            while the Borrower's was deficient. Several lessons can
            be learned from this project. First, policy related studies
            should be completed during project preparation and policy
            reforms should be undertaken before significant financial
            commitments are made. Second, technical assistance should be
            credit-financed to ensure quality and timely availability.
            Third, non-salary inputs need to be fully budgeted in the
            provincial recurrent budgets. Fourth, demand side
            initiatives should be given much more attention, as should
            the involvement of communities in the management, operation,
            and maintenance of schools. Fifth, monitoring and evaluation
            deficiencies are major constraints to sectoral planning and
            reform. Sixth, the frequent transfer of key management
            personnel is inimical to capacity building. Finally, for
            future projects, IDA and authorities need to review the
            basis on which IDA finances contracts that are procured at
            the local level by untrained administrators working with
            small contractors.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Primary Education Project
            supports the broad goal of the Government to achieve
            universal primary education by the year 2000.  The project
            concentrates on the Punjab province but also has some
            national aspects.  The main objective of the project is to
            support the core program of the Punjab's Five-Year
            primary education investment program.  The specific
            objectives include:  (a) improving institutional capacity to
            plan, manage and implement the investment program; (b)
            supporting policy reform; and (c) supporting innovations in
            the delivery of primary education.  To that end, the project
            entails (i) management improvement; (ii) curriculum
            development and materials supply; (iii) teacher training;
            (iv) communications/demand generation; and (v) finally,
            school construction.  With the last component, the project
            supports concentrating on the building of new girls schools
            and providing facilities for existing shelterless girls
            schools.  This is in line with the overall Government
            strategy to increase female enrollments.
